nodes.bodyText: I don't think this is worth a warn level - if the block was finalized during the processing it isn't a big deal if we don't recover the operations from it.
Makes sense.

We shouldn't be casting to SuccesfulBlockImportResult - it's always just a BlockImportResult and for failures isBlockOnCanonicalChain would always return false (block isn't on the canonical chain if it failed to import).
Makes sense.
Hard coded 10000 doesn't look right here.

Also I'm suspicious that we might be including the common ancestor block itself when processing a reorg.  We should process both chains only from the block after the common ancestor (ie only process the blocks that actually changed).
Yeah, I wasn't sure about 10000 as well. I need a number high enough to never be a problem, but less than the limits of UInt64 so that it never throws an ArithmeticException as well.
Added a new method to get every ancestor that does not calculate count instead of passing a magic variable.
Also made sure this method does not return the block root for the common ancestor.

This looks awfully complex and I think it still has to setup quite a lot of operations yet.  I suspect getting it all set up with valid data will be a lot of code and pretty slow.  I think I'd just do a unit test focused on OperationsReOrgManager - with a mock RecentChainData it should be fairly easy to inject the blocks we want and all we really need to see is that the operations from those blocks and added or removed from all the right places.  We know they do their job fine from there.
Makes sense. Will switch to unit tests.

If we're going to add a java doc comment we should fill it all out. :)
I also feel like this should be some variant of getAncestors so that it has a similar name to the existing getAncestors method.  Maybe getAncestorsOnFork?
Makes sense. Done.
The nesting levels here seem to have gotten a bit out of control.  Probably need to extract a method or two to reduce them.
Done.

We should preserve the stack trace instead of only logging the error message.

This method is too big overall. Probably worth splitting in two - process nonCanonical and then process canonical blocks.  And then probably a few other helper methods to make the optional/future chainings not wind up so deeply nested and hard to follow.
I tried to make it better, and its a bit better, but there is still some serious nesting. Could use suggestions.

I probably wouldn't add this method.  We want to create the ValidatableAttestation only at the key entry points but this makes it much simpler to get that wrong and create a new ValidatableAttestation without thinking about it and then we'll lose the context it tracks.
Makes sense.
Done.
Should avoid the cast to SuccessfulBlockImportResult.  Might need to make setBlockOnCanonicalChain a markAsCanonical method which throws UnsupportedOperationException for failed results.

nodes.bodyText: Probably worth having a test for when blocks are removed but not added or vice-versa (ie a reorg that only changes from an empty slot to a full one and the other way).  Should work fine but that's the most common type of reorg so important to handle it right.
I did the reOrg from an empty slot to a full one, but I'm having a hard time understanding the reOrg from full one to empty slot since attestations vote on blocks.
Should rename this to match the recentChainData method it delegates to.
Done.
Probably should have a test case for when the block root is unknown.
Done.
I'm not sure why this change was required as part of this PR.

Ok I think I can see this one being useful for the submit block API which previously was a bug.  Still not sure what's deserializing an IndexedAttestation since they should only be in states and we shouldn't parse any of those from JSON (I think).

We need to parse IndexedAttestation when we're deserializing JSON of AttesterSlashing, since it contains two IndexedAttestations.
I needed to do deal with all this JSON stuff as I made sure now our DataStructureUtil.randomBeaconBlock(int n) method always returns a block with 1 AttesterSlashing, instead of returning an empty AttesterSlashing SSZList as it used to do. This made all our tests more robust IMO.
Then it turned out that we could not deserialize BeaconBlock JSON objects which included AttesterSlashings. I saw this as the PostBlockTest.shouldReturnAcceptedIfBlockFailsValidation failed after creating and trying to deserialize a randomBeaconBlock, which now included an AttesterSlashing.
oh right of course. Yep that makes sense.
Not sure what caused this to be needed either.
Done.
We definitely shouldn't have JSON serialisation annotations in our core classes.
Artifact of intense debugging. Removed.
Why is this a new method just to reorder the params?

Its to have a configurable number of items in the SSZList. In the past, we either had the randomFullSSZList option which filled the list to its maxSize, or the default randomSSZList, which would fill each list maxSize/10 number of items.
In attester slashing, that would mean 0 items.
I'd probably have at least 3 attestations in the blocks by default.  Good to have a slashing added in there that I'm guessing wound up with none before though.
